intro.title: We will now explain the [Endoscopy Examination] and proceed with the consent process.
intro.subtitle: This will take about 2-3 minutes. The patient must listen carefully and understand the information.

pages.title: Examination Overview
pages.content: Conscious sedation, or sedation gastroscopy, involves intravenously administering sedatives to relax the patient and allow for a comfortable examination. However, the procedure is performed while the patient maintains cooperative consciousness.

pages.title: Individual Variation in Sedation
pages.content: Since patients react differently to medications, even with appropriate doses, some may not achieve sufficient sedation or sleep, or may become less cooperative, making the examination more difficult.

pages.title: Possible Side Effects
pages.content: Side effects may include respiratory issues such as breathing difficulty and hypoxia, blood pressure changes, and heart rate changes. However, these side effects are very rare, and medical staff continuously monitor patients to ensure safe examination.

pages.title: Post-Examination Precautions
pages.content: You must rest for at least 1 hour after the examination, and driving is prohibited on the same day. A guardian must accompany you, and it is advisable to avoid important tasks or decision-making on the day of the examination.

checkbox.title: Consent for Additional Tests and Costs
checkbox.content: If abnormalities are found during the endoscopy, additional tests such as biopsy or Helicobacter tests may be performed immediately for accurate diagnosis. Additional costs will be incurred. Do you consent to tissue biopsy or Helicobacter testing during the endoscopy?

signature.title: Electronic Signature
signature.instruction: Please sign directly in the signature area with your finger.

voice.title: Voice Recording
voice.instruction: Please record your consent by reading the following statement
voice.script: I have fully understood the explanation about [Endoscopy Examination], understand the purpose, procedure, and precautions, and hereby consent to the examination and treatment.

aiConsultation.greeting: Hello. I am an AI doctor. Please feel free to ask any questions about the endoscopy examination.
sampleQuestions: Can I feel pain during sedation endoscopy?
How long should I fast before the examination?
Can I drive after the examination?
How much does the examination cost?

pain.answer: Sedation endoscopy uses sedatives to keep patients comfortable during the examination. Most patients experience little to no discomfort during the procedure, and pain after the examination is usually mild. However, individual experiences may vary, and some patients may feel slight discomfort.
relatedQuestions: How long does the examination take?
How long is the recovery time?

fasting.answer: For gastroscopy, fasting for 8 hours before the examination is required. Small amounts of water can be consumed up to 2 hours before the examination. Consult with your doctor about whether to take your morning medications.
relatedQuestions: How should I take my medications?

driving.answer: Due to the effects of sedatives, driving is prohibited on the day of sedation endoscopy. A guardian must accompany you, and we recommend using public transportation or taxi. Regular endoscopy without sedation allows driving.
relatedQuestions: Can I return to work on the same day?

polyps.answer: If polyps are found, they can be removed immediately during the endoscopy depending on their size and shape. Small polyps are removed using a snare, while larger polyps may require separate procedures. Removed polyps are examined through biopsy to determine if they are benign or malignant.
relatedQuestions: What is the cost of polyp removal?

cost.answer: Basic endoscopy is covered by health insurance with a patient copay of approximately 10,000-30,000 won. Sedation endoscopy incurs an additional 30,000-50,000 won. Additional costs apply for biopsy or polyp removal. Exact costs can be confirmed after the examination.

default.answer: I'm sorry, I couldn't find an answer to that question. Please ask another question about the examination or consult directly with the medical staff.

sections.title: 1. Gastroscopy Overview
sections.content: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is the most fundamental examination for diagnosing inflammation, ulcers, and cancer occurring in the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. The examination takes about 5-10 minutes. To reduce throat discomfort, throat anesthesia is administered before the examination. As air is introduced for observation, you may experience abdominal bloating, coughing, or nausea.

sections.title: Other Complications
items: Swelling around the esophageal entrance due to gagging and coughing during examination, spasms, bleeding, foreign body sensation, throat pain
Endoscopy fever with chills and fever that improves within 24 hours after examination
Severe bleeding and infection after endoscopic biopsy, perforation (occurs very rarely)

sections.content:
If abnormalities are found during endoscopy, biopsy or Helicobacter testing may be necessary for accurate diagnosis.
Biopsy may cause slight bleeding and pain, and additional costs will be incurred. Do you consent to biopsy and Helicobacter testing?

Tissue Biopsy / Helicobacter Testing

sections.title: Patients Requiring Caution
sections.content:
During gastroscopy, dental damage (implants, dentures, resin, bridges, orthodontic/retaining devices, loose teeth) may occur if the patient bites the mouthpiece too hard, as well as lip injuries and jaw dislocation. Our clinic is not responsible for such incidents.

*If you have no TMJ disorder and have not received dental treatment on front teeth, select 'No dental issues'

sections.title: Consent Form for Conscious Sedation (Sleep) Endoscopy
Examination Overview
sections.content: Conscious sedation (sleep) endoscopy involves administering medication via injection to bring the patient to a certain level of sedation, reducing discomfort during the examination. However, this is not a procedure under general anesthesia; the examination is conducted while the patient can still cooperate. Therefore, you may experience some pain or discomfort during the examination. Also, despite using appropriate doses of medication, some patients may not achieve adequate sedation or may become less cooperative, making the examination itself difficult.
sections.highlight: This is not a procedure under general anesthesia; the examination is conducted while the patient can still cooperate. Therefore, you may experience some pain or discomfort during the examination. Also, despite using appropriate doses of medication, some patients may not achieve adequate sedation or may become less cooperative, making the examination itself difficult.

sections.title: Side Effects and Complications
sections.content:
About 10% may show paradoxical reactions (aggressive behavior such as shouting or trying to get up from bed). In such cases, an antagonist medication is administered to restore consciousness before proceeding with the examination. Respiratory complications such as breathing difficulty and hypoxia, cardiovascular complications such as rapid heartbeat or blood pressure drop (0.1-0.54%) may occur. Very rarely, it may result in irreversible conditions including death (0.03%). Allergic reactions may also occur depending on the medication administered.

After the examination, rest is required for complete recovery. You should not drive on the day of examination and should avoid important appointments or tasks. Since rest is required after sedation endoscopy, unless absolutely necessary, we recommend safer options such as regular endoscopy or upper GI series.

sections.title: Cases Where Sedation Endoscopy Cannot Be Performed
items: Various respiratory diseases (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc.)
Chronic liver diseases (chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, etc.)
Others: Sedation endoscopy is not recommended for overweight individuals or elderly patients (69 years or older)
Sedatives may cause temporary memory loss during and after the examination.
Please refrain from sedation endoscopy in the above cases. We remind you that you are responsible for any issues arising from your own actions (including accidents while driving).
For sedation endoscopy, please avoid excessive nail art as it can interfere with accurate oxygen saturation measurement.
As sedatives are administered intravenously, injection site pain, redness, and bruising may occur, and rarely, phlebitis may develop.

sections.title: Consent for Additional Tests and Costs
sections.content: If abnormalities are found during endoscopy, additional tests such as biopsy and Helicobacter testing may be performed immediately for accurate diagnosis. Additional costs will be incurred. Do you consent to tissue biopsy or Helicobacter testing during the endoscopy?

danger.title: Warning - Heart Disease
danger.content: Sedatives used during sedation endoscopy can temporarily change blood pressure or heart rate. Patients with heart disease may react sensitively to these changes, potentially triggering angina attacks or other side effects, requiring caution.

caution.title: Caution - Respiratory Disease
caution.content: Sedatives used during sedation endoscopy can temporarily change blood pressure or heart rate. Patients with heart disease may react sensitively to these changes, potentially triggering angina attacks or other side effects, requiring caution.

sections.title: Examination Overview
sections.content: Conscious sedation, or sedation gastroscopy, involves administering medication via injection to bring the patient to a certain level of sedation, reducing discomfort during the examination. However, this is not a procedure under complete anesthesia; the examination is conducted while the patient can still cooperate.

sections.title: Individual Variation in Sedation Effect
sections.content: Since patients react differently to medications, even with appropriate doses, sedation or sleep may not be sufficient, or patient cooperation may decrease, making the examination itself difficult.

sections.title: Possible Side Effects
sections.content: Side effects may include respiratory issues such as breathing difficulty and hypoxia, cardiovascular reactions such as rapid heart rate, and falls. Most cases improve without special treatment, but rarely, breathing or heart may stop, posing life-threatening situations and requiring emergency measures.

sections.title: Patients Requiring Caution
sections.content: Special caution is needed during sedation endoscopy for patients with respiratory diseases affecting lung function, or those with kidney or heart conditions.

sections.title: Post-Examination Precautions
sections.content: Complete recovery and rest are required after sedation endoscopy. Do not drive on the day of examination, and avoid important appointments or tasks. You must return home with a guardian to prevent risks such as falls.

sections.title: Consent Form Signing Guide
sections.content: I (or my guardian) have heard explanations about the necessity of sedation endoscopy, the examination process, and potential complications after the procedure, and fully understand the contents. Accordingly, I hereby apply in writing to the hospital to receive the examination and treatment.
